title: 30 American ghost towns: ZIP codes where homes have vacated the most
text:
CLOSE

There are more than 1.5 million vacant single-family houses and condos in the USA. The reasons why these homes are classified as vacant vary. Some are in popular vacation areas and are used only seasonally. Others are on the market, waiting for a renter or a buyer. Many are effectively abandoned.

Nationwide, only about 1.6% of single-family homes are vacant. In some parts of the country, however, vacancy rates are many times the national figure, exceeding 20%, and even 30% in the most extreme cases.

24/7 Wall St. reviewed the share of single-family homes that were unoccupied as of the end of the third quarter of 2019 to identify the 30 ZIP codes with the highest vacancy rates – America’s ghost towns. Vacancy rates in these areas, which were calculated by ATTOM Data Solutions using tax assessor data, range from 16% to 31.3%.

The majority of ZIP codes on this list tend to be in urban areas in the South and Midwest. The majority of these areas with nation-leading vacancy rates are in Rust Belt cities. These cities have been hollowed out by the decline of American manufacturing and have little to offer in the way of economic opportunity.

Each of the 30 ZIP codes on this list has a poverty rate of more than 30% – which is more than double the comparable national poverty rate of 14.6%. Many of these ZIP codes are concentrated within a single city. Gary, Indiana; Flint, Michigan; Cleveland; and Detroit have multiple ZIP codes on this list. These cities are relatively poor, and some rank among the poorest nationwide.

High vacancy rates are indicative of low demand for housing, and most of these areas have reported a population decline in the past five years. The reduced demand has probably led to declining home values.

In 28 of the ZIP codes on this list, the typical home is worth less than $75,000. For context, the median home value nationwide is $193,500.

Is your money safe? These states are getting hit hardest by the pension crisis

The heaviest cars on the market: Weighing more than 4 tons, this Ford truck leads the way

ZIP 48238 (Detroit) (Photo: Courtesy of Cherice J. via Yelp)

30. ZIP 48238 (Detroit)

• Vacant homes: 1,720 (16%)

• 5-year population change: -8.6%

• Population: 28,447

• Median home value: $34,800

The 48238 ZIP code is one of several in the city of Detroit with a near nation-leading vacancy rate. There are about 10,700 single-family homes in the area northwest of downtown, and 1,720 of them are vacant, or 16%.

As is the case in most places on this list, people are moving out of the 48238 ZIP code. In the past five years, the population has declined by 8.6%. The typical area home is worth $34,800.

29. ZIP 35234 (Birmingham, Alabama)

• Vacant homes: 350 (16.2%)

• 5-year population change: -10.2%

• Population: 5,446

• Median home value: $62,000

The 35234 ZIP code is just north of downtown, largely in between Interstate 20 and Interstate 65. Of the 2,167 homes in the area, 350 are vacant. The area's vacancy rate of 16.2% may be partially attributable to population decline.

More than one of three residents live below the poverty line, and most households earn less than $25,000 a year.

28. ZIP 35218 (Birmingham, Alabama)

• Vacant homes: 316 (16.2%)

• 5-year population change: -5.3%

• Population: 7,097

• Median home value: $63,800

The population exodus may be attributable in part to a lack of economic opportunity. Most area households earn less than $25,000 a year, and more than 41% of area residents live below the poverty line.

27. ZIP 46208 (Indianapolis)

• Vacant homes: 1,337 (16.4%)

• 5-year population change: 2.3%

• Population: 23,300

• Median home value: $103,900

Relatively few vacant properties in the area are abandoned; the majority are classified as investment properties, meaning they are probably either on the rental market or waiting to be sold at a profit by the owner. In the past five years, the value of the typical home fell from $108,300 to $103,900, a 4.1% drop.

26. ZIP 48205 (Detroit)

• Vacant homes: 2,138 (16.4%)

• 5-year population change: -10.5%

• Population: 34,620

• Median home value: $30,600

The typical area home is worth $30,600, down 31.7% from five years earlier, when the typical area home was worth $44,800.

25. ZIP 21217 (Baltimore)

• Vacant homes: 2,190 (16.6%)

• 5-year population change: -9.6%

• Population: 36,563

• Median home value: $130,500

Situated on the south side of Druid Hill Park in northwest Baltimore, the 21217 ZIP code covers the city's Reservoir Hill, Penn North, Druid Heights, Bolton Hill and Upton neighborhoods. Across Baltimore as a whole, there are about 17,000 vacant properties, which have dragged down property values for about a decade.

Of the 2,190 vacant homes in the area, more than 1,500 are classified as investment properties, which suggests that their owners may be renovating them or waiting for them to appreciate to sell. Unlike many ZIP codes on this list, property values are on the rise in this part of Baltimore. The typical area home is worth $130,500, a 15.6% increase from the median home value in the area five years earlier.

24. ZIP 15110 (Duquesne, Pennsylvania)

• Vacant homes: 345 (16.6%)

• 5-year population change: -0.7%

• Population: 5,544

• Median home value: $37,800

The 15110 ZIP code in western Pennsylvania sits along the west bank of the Monongahela River. Of the 2,075 residential properties in the area, 345 are vacant. Most area households earn less than $25,000 a year, and 36.3% of area residents live below the poverty line.

Home values in the area are low and do not appear to be improving. The typical area home is worth $37,800, down from $38,300 five years earlier.

23. ZIP 44112 (Cleveland)

• Vacant homes: 1,148 (16.7%)

• 5-year population change: -3.6%

• Population: 21,788

• Median home value: $59,800

The number of vacant properties has increased substantially in recent months.

Most area households earn less than $23,000 a year, and 38.7% of area residents live in poverty.

22. ZIP 21223 (Baltimore)

• Vacant homes: 2,093 (16.7%)

• 5-year population change: -1%

• Population: 23,811

• Median home value: $68,900

Baltimore's 21223 ZIP code is one of only a few mid-Atlantic areas – and one of only two ZIP codes in Maryland – to rank on this list.

The city as a whole has had a vacancy problem for some time. For the past 10 years, there have been about 17,000 vacant buildings across the city. In an effort to reduce that number, Housing Commissioner Michael Braverman pledged to demolish about 2,000 of them in the next year. The 21223 ZIP code has already seen some improvement, as there are about 60 fewer vacant properties than there were a year ago.

21. ZIP 46404 (Gary, Indiana)

• Vacant homes: 1,073 (16.9%)

• 5-year population change: 2.7%

• Population: 17,441

• Median home value: $69,600

Gary, a town founded by a steel company, has been in steady decline along with the American steel industry since the mid-20th century. The city's population peaked at more than 178,000 in 1960 and has since been cut by more than half.

ZIP 47305 (Muncie, Ind.) (Photo: Nyttend / Wikimedia Commons)

20. ZIP 47305 (Muncie, Indiana)

• Vacant homes: 202 (16.9%)

• 5-year population change: -12.1%

• Population: 3,639

• Median home value: $53,300

More than 3,600 people live in the ZIP code.

Economic opportunities are often scarce in places with such a steep population decline, and Muncie's 47305 ZIP code is no exception. Most area households have an income of less than $24,000 a year, and 42.5% of the population live below the poverty line.

19. ZIP 45214 (Cincinnati)

• Vacant homes: 277 (17%)

• 5-year population change: 0.3%

• Population: 8,366

• Median home value: $62,100

The majority of vacant properties in the area are classified as investment properties. Despite the high vacancy rate, property in the area appears to be appreciating in value. In the past five years, the typical home increased in value by 8.4%, from $57,300 to $62,100.

18. ZIP 46406 (Gary, Indiana)

• Vacant homes: 599 (17.2%)

• 5-year population change: -4.4%

• Population: 9,462

• Median home value: $54,600

Gary was founded and operated by U.S. Steel. As the steel industry declined, so did Gary. The city has faced widespread socioeconomic problems, including drugs, violent crime and widespread poverty.

Many of the vacant properties in this part of Gary are investment properties. It may be a while before a real estate investment in the area pays off. The typical area home is worth $54,600, down 10.2% from five years ago. Over the same period, the typical American home has appreciated in value by 9.5%.

17. ZIP 63115 (St. Louis)

• Vacant homes: 1,276 (17.3%)

• 5-year population change: -10.7%

• Population: 18,799

• Median home value: $55,000

The 63115 ZIP code is just north of the Central West End neighborhood along O'Fallon Park. It is one of several parts of the Missouri city to have near nation-leading home vacancy rates. The problem has gotten considerably worse. Last year, there were only 670 vacant properties in the area.

High vacancy rates can be tied to higher crime rates, and St. Louis is a relatively dangerous city. There were 455 violent crimes in greater St. Louis for every 100,000 people, well above the national violent crime rate of 369 per 100,000.

16. ZIP 46016 (Anderson, Indiana)

• Vacant homes: 1,248 (17.6%)

• 5-year population change: -3.1%

• Population: 18,300

• Median home value: $41,500

The urban decay evidenced by the large share of vacant properties is due in part to poor regional economic conditions. About 38.2% of area residents live below the poverty line, more than double the 14.6% national poverty rate.

Anderson is within the Indianapolis metro area, which ranks among the most dangerous in the country. There were 642 violent crimes for every 100,000 people in greater Indianapolis in 2018, far more than the 369 per 100,000 national violent crime rate.

15. ZIP 39203 (Jackson, Mississippi)

• Vacant homes: 343 (17.7%)

• 5-year population change: -6.2%

• Population: 6,250

• Median home value: $48,600

Few parts of the USA are as poor as the 39203 ZIP code around downtown, west of the Farish Street Historic District. Nearly half of all area residents live below the poverty line, and most households live on less than $20,000 a year.

14. ZIP 45402 (Dayton, Ohio)

• Vacant homes: 725 (18.3%)

• 5-year population change: -8.9%

• Population: 9,568

• Median home value: $56,200

Dayton's 45402 ZIP is centrally located and bisected by the Great Miami River.

The area's population decline is most likely attributable to poor economic conditions. The typical household in the area earns less than $25,000 a year, and more than 42% of the population live in poverty, making the area one of the poorest in the USA.

13. ZIP 48504 (Flint, Michigan)

• Vacant homes: 1,981 (18.5%)

• 5-year population change: -7.5%

• Population: 28,316

• Median home value: $33,000

In a plan to reduce costs, Flint switched its water source from Lake Huron to the Flint River in April, 2014. Less than a year later, the EPA reported dangerous concentrations of lead in the water supply. The contaminated water resulted in a public health crisis and criminal investigations against city officials.

In the past five years, property values fell by 30.5%.

12. ZIP 63133 (St. Louis)

• Vacant homes: 495 (18.5%)

• 5-year population change: -11.1%

• Population: 7,299

• Median home value: $54,900

The 63133 ZIP code is north of Washington University and bisected by route 180.

The typical area home is worth $54,900, down 11.6% from the median home value in the area of $62,100 five years ago.

11. ZIP 48206 (Detroit)

• Vacant homes: 1,056 (18.6%)

• 5-year population change: -20.2%

• Population: 16,905

• Median home value: $48,100

Detroit's 48206 ZIP code is contained almost entirely by I-94 and I-96 on the south and west and routes 10 and 8 on the east and north. Few cities have been hit as hard by the decline of American manufacturing as Detroit.

Nearly 38% of area residents live below the poverty line, and the unemployment rate across the broader Detroit metro area stands at 4.5% as of August, well above the comparable national unemployment rate of 3.8%.

ZIP 44108 (Cleveland) (Photo: Tim Evanson / Flickr)

10. ZIP 44108 (Cleveland)

• Vacant homes: 1,552 (18.6%)

• 5-year population change: -13%

• Population: 22,048

• Median home value: $56,400

The 44108 ZIP code is along the shore of Lake Erie. The rapid population decline has led to reduced demand for housing. The typical area home is worth $56,400, down 15.3% from half a decade ago.

Like most ZIP codes on this list, 44108 is in a city that has long suffered economically from the decline of American manufacturing. Since the industry began to decline and factories began to close in the mid-20th century, the city's population was more than halved, from more than 900,000 as of 1950 to less than 400,000.

9. ZIP 63113 (St. Louis)

• Vacant homes: 863 (18.9%)

• 5-year population change: -8.6%

• Population: 11,184

• Median home value: $65,800

Many of the vacant properties are investment properties. The typical area home is worth $65,800, down 1.2% from five years ago. Over the same period, the typical American home has appreciated in value by 9.5%.

8. ZIP 64128 (Kansas City, Missouri)

• Vacant homes: 934 (18.9%)

• 5-year population change: -2.3%

• Population: 12,056

• Median home value: $38,900

The 64128 ZIP code covers the Knoches Park, Oak Park Northwest, Palestine East and Sante Fe neighborhoods, as well as Ingleside, a particularly high crime neighborhood. In Kansas City, violent crime – especially homicide – tends to be concentrated in areas with high vacant property rates.

The typical home is worth $38,900, 22% less than it was worth five years ago.

7. ZIP 44507 (Youngstown, Ohio)

• Vacant homes: 437 (21.5%)

• 5-year population change: -8%

• Population: 5,093

• Median home value: $22,100

As in most places reporting a population decline and a high vacancy rate, property values are near rock bottom. The typical area home is worth $22,100, about $170,000 below the value of the typical American home.

Economic problems and population decline across Youngstown began in the 1970s and '80s, when the city's once dominant steel industry declined. The lack of economic opportunity in the area remains a root cause of the high vacancy rate. Across the broader Youngstown metro area, August 2019 unemployment stands at 6%, well above the 3.8% national unemployment rate.

6. ZIP 17976 (Shenandoah, Pennsylvania)

• Vacant homes: 759 (23.9%)

• 5-year population change: -3.1%

• Population: 6,715

• Median home value: $34,700

Pennsylvania’s 17976 ZIP code comprises the borough of Shenandoah, about 140 miles west of New York City. An economically depressed area, 38.6% of residents live below the poverty line, and more than half of all area homes are worth less than $35,000. Low property values and high vacancy rates tend to go hand in hand.

A coal mining town in the early 1900s, Shenandoah has long been in decline. The industry all but shut down in the area more than half a century ago.

5. ZIP 36104 (Montgomery, Alabama)

• Vacant homes: 591 (24%)

• 5-year population change: -10%

• Population: 8,040

• Median home value: $74,200

The 36104 ZIP code along Gun Island Chute is one of several parts of the state capital with a near nation-leading home vacancy rate. Of the vacant homes, 491 are classified as investment properties.

Home values have not appreciated in the area in recent years. The typical home in the ZIP code is worth $74,200, 6.9% less than it was worth five years ago.

4. ZIP 46407 (Gary, Indiana)

• Vacant homes: 1,306 (28.2%)

• 5-year population change: -8.9%

• Population: 11,657

• Median home value: $51,600

People have been leaving the area in droves in recent years. From 2013 to 2017, the median home value in the area fell by 9.9%, from $57,300 to $51,600.

3. ZIP 46409 (Gary, Indiana)

• Vacant homes: 1,190 (30.8%)

• 5-year population change: -16.7%

• Population: 7,625

• Median home value: $59,500

The 46409 ZIP code is bordered by Route 53, I-94, and I-65. Like many neighborhoods on this list, the 46409 ZIP code is a poor place. More than one in every three residents live below the poverty line, more than double the 14.6% national poverty rate.

2. ZIP 46402 (Gary, Indiana)

• Vacant homes: 648 (31.3%)

• 5-year population change: -7.2%

• Population: 6,128

• Median home value: $59,000

Of the several neighborhoods in Gary, Indiana, to rank on this list, none has a larger share of vacant homes than the 46402 ZIP, which extends from Central Avenue to the Lake Michigan shore. The typical home in the ZIP code is worth $59,000, a fraction of the median home value of $193,500 nationwide.

Low home values have created an opportunity for real estate investors in the area. There are 447 vacant homes classified as investment properties. Whether those investments will bear fruit any time soon remains to be seen.

ZIP 48505 (Flint, Mich.) (Photo: Courtesy of Daniel H. via Yelp)

1. ZIP 48505 (Flint, Michigan)

• Vacant homes: 3,041 (31.3%)

• 5-year population change: -9.7%

• Population: 21,086

• Median home value: $22,700

Few parts of the country have known the level of urban decay that Flint has. The city, which was economically distressed after the declining presence of General Motors as a major employer, was hit with a public health crisis after it was discovered in 2015 that the city's water supply was contaminated with dangerous levels of lead.

The crisis pushed many out of the city and provided little incentive for any would-be buyers to invest in area real estate. The typical house is worth $22,700.

Methodology

To identify America’s 30 ghost towns, 24/7 Wall St. reviewed the share of single-family homes and condos that are unoccupied in 16,148 ZIP codes with at least 1,000 single family homes and condos. Occupancy status was determined by ATTOM Data Solutions using tax assessor data for the end of the third quarter in 2019.

To better identify areas with vacancy rates that remain high year round and are not likely to decrease significantly in the near future, we considered only ZIP codes with five-year population growth of less than 5%. We excluded ZIP codes where a large share of properties are vacant probably because of seasonal variation. This includes beach towns and places and other vacation destinations.

Median household income, median home value, poverty rates and population at the ZIP code level are all five-year estimates from the U.S. Census Bureau’s 2017 American Community Survey. Five-year changes in population and median home value from 2013 to 2017 are also from the ACS. Violent crime and homicide rates at the metro area level are from the FBI’s 2018 Uniform Crime Report.

24/7 Wall Street is a USA TODAY content partner offering financial news and commentary. Its content is produced independently of USA TODAY.

Read or Share this story: https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/2019/10/16/30-american-ghost-towns/40318675/
description: 24/7 Wall St. reviewed the share of homes that were unoccupied as of the end of the third quarter of 2019 to identify modern ghost towns in the USA.
